business.name: Bistrot La Minette
business.categories: Restaurants, French, Breakfast & Brunch

reviews.text:
My friend and I came here for Center city restaurant week! 
We love french food and were excited to try this place based on the great reviews. 
When we first walked in we were greater by the staff. They offered coat check and we were seated right away. They gave us complementary cheese puffs and french bread with delicious house made butter. For appetizers we got the foie gras (first time trying) + escargots. Foie gras was definitely an acquired tasted. It was good but a bit too salty for my taste. The escargots were delicious and buttery. 

For entrees we got the mustard brazed rabbit and coq au vin! Both were good portions of food. Both were super delicious in their own way. 

Dessert we got the creme brulee and raspberry puffs. The creme brulee was creamy and delicious however the top sugar portion was alittle burnt for me. The puff pastry was very delicious. Overall food, service and experience was top notch! Would love to come back again next time I'm craving french food :)

Came here for January 2022 Restaurant Week. Very cute date night vibes and meeting you with friends. Our waitress Nicole was so patient and great with providing recommendations! Would definitely recommend the escargot and mustard braised rabbit!
Went during restraint week and wish chose otherwise.  Food was cold, waiting staff was below average and prices ridiculous.

Restaurant week 2022 experience!! 

Ambience is very dim and calm inside, can see into the kitchen, nice little setup. 

Menu had a good amount of options in terms of variety. Something for everyone imo no major beef dish though. Chicken pork fish and rabbit were options for restaurant week (full menu probably had a beef option but I didn't look)

To start. My wife got the escargot and I got the foie gras. Both did the trick and Are recommended. The house bread and butter was a hit as well. 

For main course I got the rabbit pasta dish. I was worried that the rabbit might be too gamey but it honestly could've passed for chicken. Well put together dish but for new rabbit eaters be careful of tiny bones 

My wife got coq au vin which had potatoes mushrooms and pork belly and I don't think you can go wrong with that dish. 

Desserts were the star of the show. Mille feuilles pastry was a show stopper and the crème brûlée was top tier as well. Recommend both. 

Restaurant week was 40 for 3 courses. Solid portions for the money. 4 stars!!!

Dined here recently for a rehearsal dinner & already planning to go back during the January restaurant week. 

Cozy ambiance, excellent selection of liquor and wine. The house wine pitchers were a huge hit.

There was a prefixed menu for the rehearsal dinner, but I throughly enjoyed the butternut squash soup, beet gnocchi in celery purée, and chocolate sea salt custard. The bread was also so amazing the entire private party kept asking for refills! The service was very attentive for such a large group. 

So glad I found this gem!

Date we dined here: Sat 13 Nov 2021
Overall a wonderful meal that was well served. 4.5 stars
* Oeuf de  pêcheur (poached egg, toast, mussels, tarragon cream): savory, unctuous, just fantastic
* Roasted butternut squash soup (crème fraîche, sage, nutmeg, pumpkin seeds): epic! easily one of the most delicious soups I've ever tasted.
* Boeuf bourguignonne: very tasty rendition of this dish. 
* Braised pork cheeks (warm spice, Puy lentils, flageolet beans, carrots, Brussels sprouts, orange, hazelnuts): This was slightly disappointing. The flavor combinations were excellent as were the various textures of the components of the dish. However, it was served dry, without any of the braising liquid which was surprising...the gravy from a braise is always very flavorful. I think it was also a slightly over-salted...not to the point of ruining the dish, but to the point of "wow...this is salty".
* Tarte tatin: a deconstructed version of this French bistro standby that was unusual in appearance and presentation, and tasted very good.
* Pot de Crème au Chocolat: very nice 

The sliced baguette was delicious, excellent French bread.

The restaurant is charming and comfortable. Noise level is low. Wait staff is unobtrusive, accommodating, and best of all...trained! They know what they are doing and they did it very well!

Definitely a place to return to

So I love French restaurants. And I don't feel there's a massive variety in philly. I've been to parc and it's cool. But I wanted something more homey less touristy and most important : SERVES BOEUF BOURGUIGNON!!!!!! as far as I know only two places meet this massively important criteria. Parc and bistrot la minette. It was our 4 year anniversary and I chose this place. Obviously. Because anyone who knows good food and culture knows boeuf Bourguignon is the top tier of all dishes. Duh. Anyway so we get here and it's a 13 min walk in my adorable queen village neighborhood which is just amazing. I love this area of philly I think it's the best in the city. And I am blown away by the interior design and how cute and French it is. So cozy and unique. Literally everything I've ever dreamed of. We started with escargot and they were very very good. Literally loved. Loved that we got bread too. I mean can it get any better than that? My boyfriend got Lapin rôti à la moutarde (mustard braised rabbit with tagliatelle and rabbit jus) and I of course got boeuf Bourguignon. It was so freaking good. I do wish it was served on mashed potato's but that's not the point. The beef was perfect. And the sauce was exactly what I wanted. And my boyfriend was also blown away by his dish. We are huge rabbit fans. Always top notch at a French restaurant. To die for. So delicious. Oh and I forgot to mention the cheese puffs they randomly gave us were also absolute fire. Lol. I can't wait to come back. It's close to home which is dangerous for me. Way better than parc it's just far more unique and cute very antique and botiquey and not a big tourtist spot /cliche. I prefer this type of spot.

Attentive waiter. Get the next level upgraded red house wine. Delicious poached egg and mussels on toast app. Rich pork cheeks and roasted veg main. Awesome apple tart dessert to finish. Good Covid-friendly outdoor setup with powerful heaters

The Culinary Adventures of Tom Coghlan, FB

Saturday was my Birthday... I took myself out to eat... I went to Bistrot La Minette at 623 s. 6th st. , near Bainbridge. I have been eating at the Bistro for over ten years... I found it one night while riding my motorcycle.(How I find a lot of Restaurants) Founder and Proprietor, Peter Woolsey ",as an adolescent, started cooking breakfast foods and pasta sauces by his father's side. On a whim he decided to attend Johnson and Wales for the culinary arts and immediately fell in love with cooking as a profession. In the late 90's he began his professional career cooking at the Sun Valley Resort and New York's Waldorf=Astoria. In 2000 he moved to France to study pastry at Le Cordon Bleu. In Paris, Peter worked for the world famous three-star Michelin restaurant, Lucas Carton, under Alain Senderens and Frederic Robert. In 2002 he moved back to Philadelphia working at George Perrier's Le Mas Perrier and the Striped Bass under Alfred Portale and Chris Lee. In 2004 he married French native Peggy Baud-Woolsey. In 2008 he opened Bistrot La Minette only five months after the birth of his son Jules. In 2014 Peter opened La Peg, an American brasserie, at the FringeArts Theater and in 2019 he opened Gabi, a French café, on North Broad with Bistrot La Minette alumnus Kenneth Bush and Brad Histand."  Since the bar was closed for seating I was seated at a high top table in the front of the restaurant looking out the window and by the bar. I met by server/bartender, Chris and ordered a Vodka and Tonic with Lime in a rocks glass.. A bucket of baguette accompanied my drink with several slices of baguette and a crock of butter that was sprinkled with Sea Salt, I ate the bread as I viewed the menu and listened to the specials. I already knew I was ordering the escargot !  I get it every time I'm here. The Burgundy snails are served in thimble like cups with garlic and Herb Butter and topped with a crouton... Chris recommended a Cotes du Rhone to compliment the coarse...Magnificent ! I then had a special of the day, a charcuterie plate consisting of several baguette slices, sausage slices, cornichons, mustard and a duck parfait made with emulsified duck liver and dark meat. It was covered in a wine gelee'. I used a butter knife to spread the duck on a baguette and enjoyed it with a glass of Beaujolais that Chris recommended ...  It was soooo good ! My main course was also a special of the day... Wild Boar with Carrots, Potatoes and lardon...Lardon are cubes of bacon that in this case were braised perfectly, providing the perfect amount of char to enhance the flavors !  It was all in a red wine sauce that absorbed the flavors of the meats yet still provided a nice contrast to the flavors !  A glass of Bordeaux accompanied my Boar and was perfect... Chris really hooked me up !At the end of my meal a plate was served to me with a lit candle and Birthday message written in fine chocolate... It was an Amazing night !

A new Philly favorite! I came for restaurant week and got the snails as an appetizer, trout as the main meal, and creme brûlée for dessert. Everything was A+ particularly the trout. The restaurant is quiet and spacious, with the tables well spaced out. Location wise, it's far enough off of South Street for it to be quiet and removed from the usual South Street shenanigans.

Great food from a low key and unpretentious restaurant.

I came here for restaurant week, and it was a really good meal. I hadn't tried a lot of French restaurants in Philly, and this meal has really encouraged me to try more of this cuisine in Philly. 

I had the Euf du pecheur and Escargot for my first course. Both of which were delicious, and were definitely the highlight of the meal. The Euf du pecheur was essentially a mussels eggs benedict--the tastes of the mussels, eggs, and creamy sauce blended together really well.  The Escargot was essentially a classic escargot dish in small bowls served with croutons.

For the main course, I had the Confit de canard (Duck confit) and the Poulet a la Provencale (White wine braised chicken). Both the duck and the chicken were really tender. The duck was on the sweeter side as it was served on top of plum and honey. The chicken was served in a white wine sauce with tomatoes, shallots, and capers, and was likewise really delicious.

The dessert, on the other hand, was a bit underwhelming. I had the Mille Feuille aux Framboises and the Baies Melangees au Cognac. The Mille Feuille was a raspberry based puff pastry, and the Baies Melangees was composed of mixed berries, candied almonds, yogurt, and honey. I would not really strongly recommend any of the desserts that I had.

Overall, I had a really good time, and I would recommend this restaurant to anyone craving french cuisine in Philly.

This is a classic French Bistro.  Simple, classic, not expensive.
I love the Croque Monsieur or Croque Madame sandwiches; like a gourmet grilled ham & cheese with Béchamel sauce, the homestyle pâté with correct cornichon pickles etc.  Everything is simple yet correct.  It delivers me to a little café on a side street in Paris.

I will start saying that the food and ambiance were really good.  The flavors and the quality and flavors of their food were superb,the kitchen service took care of every little detail and presentation/ambiance truly make you feel you we're having a special dinning experience.
My biggest complaint is front of the house, especially the lady that was working on the 24th and 25th of September.  I had made a reservation for 3 people when Center City Restaurant started for Saturday night.  I called on Friday asking if they could accommodate one more, the lady was rude and rushed me off the phone saying they couldn't.  I called again on Saturday and pleaded to add the extra person and tried to reason that the table for 3 most likely could fit 4.  Once again she was extremely rude and said no.  So my friend cancelled since we couldn't make it to 4.  To my dismay and extreme frustration, not only the table could have accommodated 4 like I thought but the amount of available and empty tables were just too painful to watch.  Knowing that after covid restaurants are trying to come back, can't understand why she would turn that extra person down to just have empty tables, and kind of running what would have been a fun night with friends.  I strongly encourage the restaurant to better coached that lady since it is a pity that she does not embrace the hard work the rest of the crew is doing and special place the bistro can be.

I will start saying that the food and ambiance were really good.  The flavors and the quality and flavors of their food were superb,the kitchen service took care of every little detail and presentation/ambiance truly make you feel you we're having a special dinning experience.
My biggest complaint is front of the house, especially the lady that was working on the 24th and 25th of September. To my dismay and extreme frustration, not only the table could have accommodated 4 like I thought but the amount of available and empty tables were just too painful to watch.  Knowing that after covid restaurants are trying to come back, can't understand why she would turn that extra person down to just have empty tables, and kind of running what would have been a fun night with friends.  I strongly encourage the restaurant to better coached that lady since it is a pity that she does not embrace the hard work the rest of the crew is doing and special place the bistro can be.

All around great - great service, all of our courses were wonderful, nice distancing for COVID...even the bread was great. My husband had the duck, which was delicious. I had the trout, which was one of the best pieces of fish I've ever had in Philadelphia.

Cue the Edith Piaf for this classic French bistro. The duck breast, trout, green salad, and peach tart were all excellent. The wine list is modest but well curated. Service was friendly and attentive. It's great for a date whether it's a first date or a date night. We also appreciated that they seated parties at every other table for both comfort and safety.

Do not come here. As a physician and after a long day I was excited to see a French restaurant and proceeded to go in and have a seat. Shortly after being seated I was greeted by a hostess who was very rude, when she found out I did not have a reservation. I'm getting up I asked her if I could use an available iPhone charger as my iPhone was on 3%, she proceeded to walk away and go all the way to the back and came back with a smirk on her face and told me no sorry. I understand that people have reservations, I definitely understand about social distancing due to Covid. However it was not a reason to be short or rude with someone that just wanted to come in and enjoy a nice dinner.

This is absolutely a must try! Delicious French restraint in Philadelphia, one of my favorites. I've been here a bunch of times and I'm sad to see that it hasn't been open during covid. Their bread is SO GOOD, I think I ate a whole baguette. If you're not sure what to get, the restaurant week menu is always a great intro but once you taste the food, you'll fall in love and come back for more. I hope they survive and reopen soon.
I've been so sad this place has been closed since COVID started. I dream of their deconstructed Mille fait :(

A Philly restaurant that reminds you of eating in Paris...

Yes, Bistro La Minette is it. Chef Peter provided me Paris Restaurant recommendations years ago. When I returned home from Paris, I realized that Paris cuisine and culture was right in my backyard.

Every dish is cooked to perfection. The bread and butter to start kicks off a fantastic evening. The butter is ROOM TEMP - that is the only way restaurants should serve butter with bread. A little sprinkle of salt and spread over a fresh piece of bread. *Poof* you just time traveled to Paris by food. Never had a disappointing dish and would order every item if I had 6 stomachs to fit it all - including dessert! I look forward to returning to Bistro once Covid-19 is over, and I hope to see you there!

If you are looking for a place to wine and dine, you already know there are certain cuisines that cater to that atmosphere. This little French bistro in Bella Vista is certainly one of them.

We had reservations during their happy hour (which at the time, was running half-price menu) - so definitely keep an eye out for that.

Really great wait staff, extremely friendly as soon as we walked in the door. They have coat room to make your sitting feel that much more comfortable. This is important to point out, because it is a tight space, but that just makes the whole atmosphere feel that much more warm and exciting. 

Their plates are all very elegant and true to french fashion - they are very creative and focus on combinations with fresh herbs and vegetables to go with their meat entrees. I would argue that if you are looking for just a classic/plain-jane meal - you won't want to come here. This is an opportunity to try some things outside of the norm, whether it be rabbit, snail, or quail. 

All of their food was just downright delicious, I think we would have just liked to see more vegetarian entree options on the menu. Their dessert menu is definitely something you can't pass on, with lots of options that have fruit (personal fav.)  

Check this place out!

This is my special occasion meal in Philly. You have to order the right things but if you do your meal will be incredible:

For appetizers, get the escargot and the fisherman's poached egg, skip the foie gras

For main, get the lamb, duck, beef, and I hear the trout is excellent too, skip the rabbit

For dessert you can't really go wrong, but I would definitely go for one of the classic French specialties to really appreciate the delicate flavors and textures that they're famous for

I would describe the ambience as intimate with an older Victorian-style decor.
Was a bit underwhelming and food came out on the colder side.  taste was below what I expected possibly because restaurant week.

Went twice last just before the Covid 
Always good food and taste fish and steaks 
Inventive food and staple French food
Good wine and drinks
Nice atmosphere
Excellent deserts

We have been missing dinners from Bistrot la Minette, so when we saw that they were now offering takeout, we were delighted. We weren't disappointed. They're offering 3-course dinners for $35, including the amuse bouche gougére, their excellent baguette and butter, and the chocolate truffles they always placed on the table with the check. 

We chose warm potato and leek soup, Boeuf Bourguignon, Poulet a la Catalan, Chocolate torte, and créme caramel. Everything was prepared to their usual high standards. Portions were generous, enough for my husband and I to each enjoy a second dinner the next evening. I'm editing to say that for some reason Yelp didn't include all of our photos. Sorry. 

They are also offering a la carte appetizers, salads, and sides. 

It is a bargain at this price, for this quality. We will be ordering again.

business.name: Vetri Cucina
business.categories: Italian, Cuban, Restaurants

reviews.text: The staff here was amazing, you didn't feel "waited on" you definitely felt they were invested in your happiness. The appetizers were delicious, the signature cocktails phenomenal, and the dinner was planned perfectly. I left full and happy.
Probably the best wine pairing I've ever had! The staff was so knowledgeable and welcoming. The momster and I had the loveliest of times celebrating our birthdays here together!

Philadelphia is lucky to have Vetri Cucina. Five years after my first visit (and over two decades after they first opened their doors), Vetri is still making the best food and providing the warmest, most complete dining experience in the city.

Every impression and feeling from my first visit has only improved. The most recent time I dined at Vetri, my dining partner and I were blown away by the tortellini in seafood brodo (impossibly delicate and yet so flavorful!) and the roasted goat, which was, in the words of my partner, "the single best bite I've ever had." Also, if it's on the menu, get the molten pistachio cake. It's incredible - possibly my favorite dessert ever.

Service is always impeccable and welcoming, from the moment the maître d' greets you to the friendly goodbyes as you walk out the door. A shoutout to Bobby - who described the goat dish so wonderfully, I think it made the dish taste even better - and Zeke, who were and have been memorably wonderful.

We spent over $300 on our meal for two, and it was worth that and more to see every bite bring an expression of wonderment and joy to my dining partner's face. Vetri encapsulates what a special dining experience should be - expertly executed cuisine without the pretention, and an overall experience that leaves diners feeling fuller - both in regards to food and happiness - than when they walked in the door.

The desserts were impeccable. I have a personal thing against lava cakes (they're not bad, but not worth the fuss in my book), but the molten pistachio cake really surprised me. And the palette cleanser? Absolutely crushed it. I did not expect such a unique combination of flavors in Philadelphia. 

Unfortunately, I did find each individual savory course a bit "one note," i.e. the amuse (although *intentionally* burnt) only tasted of char, the veal tartare was overpowered with brown butter, and both the pici as well as the branzino were too salty. I did not finish the branzino and my guest and I had to swap some of our dishes. 

HOWEVER, service was perfect and that's why Vetri gets 5 stars in my book.  What the food that night lacked was made up for by the rockstar FOH staff. My server kindly asked me multiple times if I would like something instead of the branzino when I didn't seem to enjoy it - it's on me for not speaking up! I didn't want to cause a fuss, but I don't think they would have minded/been mean about it. 

At the end of the day, Vetri may not be the first thing I recommend to someone in town, but the meal ended on a high note and I'd go back in the future.

A special restaurant for a special occasion.  Food is superb, the wine options and pairing are equally excellent.

The highlight for us, luckily for two visits over the past 10 years, was our server Bill.  Easily the best service we have ever experienced.

Not sure how we've gone so many years without trying Vetri but got the chance to visit recently and I was very pleasantly surprised how much we enjoyed our meal. I think I had been hesitant because some people had told me the portions were not enough but I have to tell you we were STUFFED. Between the complimentary appetizer and amuse bouche, I think the number of courses would have been enough. But we added a third pasta and the prosciutto board and it was way too much food for the two of us.

Everything was excellent. Highlights for me were the duck garganelli pasta, the fried pizza dough complimentary appetizer, and my duck breast entree. The other dishes were very good too but those were definitely my favorite. Not pictured are our desserts, the ricotta cheesecake and the chocolate mousse cake. 

I also want to highlight that the service was impeccable! My husband spilled his espresso and they covered it up and got him a new one. And I started not feeling too well during dinner and they kindly packaged all our leftovers so well. Can't wait to go back!

I really enjoy this place, the food, the atmosphere, the people everybody was accommodating and friendly. It's a place you will have to try for yourself I highly recommend it. I would definitely go back and try other menus.

Each dish was perfection.  The gnocchi was beyond amazing. The pistachio dessert was delightful. Also the wine pairing elevated our culinary experience to a whole new level. Bobby- we hit the lotto having you as both our sommelier and waiter! Enrique- thank you for being the most gracious host!

I wanted to love Vetri more than I did. We had the tasting menu, and there certainly were some highlights. We ordered the Stuzzichini with the prosciutto and coppa. This was very good, but I didn't care as much for the tigelle which came with it. These little pieces of fried bread had an unpleasant texture.

The Sweet Onion Crepe was the best thing I ate all evening. It had the purest distillation of amazing caramelized onion flavor that I have ever experience. I would order this again in a heartbeat. I also tried the Swordfish Braciole, which was delicious.

The Gnocchi was another highlight. The potato-less dumplings had the most beautiful texture, and the brown butter sauce lent the gnocchi a richness that was amazing. I was less pleased with the Spaghetti Alla Chitarra. Overall, I found that the sauce lacked flavor, and I would not reorder this pasta.

My husband and I split the Veal Milanese. While it was an excellent cut of veal and had some truly beautiful heirloom tomatoes, I felt this dish lacked flavor as well. 

Both desserts that we tried were outstanding. I loved the Black Forest Tiramisu, finding the additional of cherries to be absolutely delicious. I was even more surprised by the Molten Pistachio Cake. This was a delight, and I would order it again.

My husband and I went here a couple nights ago for an early anniversary dinner and it was one of the best meals of my life. Service was exquisite, the ambiance was charming, and the food was incredible.

Service: From the phone call to confirm our reservation to wishing us goodbye as we left the service could not have been better. Our servers made wonderful recommendations, topped off our wine often, and brought us extra goodies throughout the evening. Note: Service is not fast, it is intentionally relaxed and spaced out so you can enjoy yourself. I never felt like we had to wait too long for any course, but if you haven't been to a restaurant like this before the paving might seem unfamiliar. 

Ambiance: The restaurant is on two levels of a row house. It's definitely not a large space, but they've made the most of it.  I didn't feel crowded at our table as there is plenty of space between tables so everyone has some privacy. But tables were close enough so we could see people's food as it was being brought out to their tables, which we enjoyed. Lighting was low, but not too low, the bathroom was exceptionally clean, the dishes and glasses all beautiful and charming. 

Food: They offer a structured menu from which you choose one option among many for each course. Every single thing I ordered was amazing! From the savory caramelized onion crepe with truffle, to the locally foraged mushroom ragu pasta, to the veal Milanese, to the pistachio cake with strawberry ice cream, every dish was exquisite. I

Also: We sprang for the wine pairings with each course and were really glad we did. Supposedly we were supposed to get a half a glass per course but it was definitely more like a whole glass each time! The wines were perfectly chosen for each dish and our servers were happy to tell us all about them. 

My husband took me to the French Laundry for a milestone e birthday a few years ago when we lived in California, and I enjoyed Vetri Cucina more, and that's saying something. If I could give 6 stars, I would. So, if you are looking for the perfect restaurant to celebrate something significant, or to propose, this is definitely the spot!

I made a reservation on Tock, this restaurant's online booking portal, on June 12 th for July 16 th. They required a $50 credit card charge to hold the reservation which I provided on American Express. On the night of the reservation they said they had no reservation for me and turned me away. I had given up a reservation at Zahav to eat at this place and ended up eating bar food after driving 5 hours to Philly. This places online reservation portal obviously does not work so please check before you go and get stuck like we did.

Vetri Cucina is phenomenal. Hands down one of the best meals we have ever had. It's a beautiful restaurant  located in a town house in Philly and offers a $125 pp prix fix style menu. Note that the website now says $135 pp.

We had;

Foie gras pastrami - excellent 
Torched Hamachi - very good
Barbecued quail - excellent 
Grano Arso Tonnarelli - very good
Swiss Chard Gnocchi - excellent 
Veal Milanese for 2 - incredible (best veal Milanese I've ever had) 
Chocolate Polenta Soufflé - good

We were blown away with our experience at Vetri!

This is both a warning and a word of encouragement...it's going to be expensive! They have a $125 prefix plating option, but if you can swing it, you will see it is well worth it. 

Honestly, walking into the restaurant, I was king of surprised. I knew this was going to be a high-end/fine dining experience, but the you could pass right by the building if you aren't familiar with the city. It's like it intentionally wants to be a secret. And the decor inside is super homey, antique-ish, rich, and warm (not a ton of glitz and glam.) Yet, as soon as you sit down, you see how it is a fine-dining experience. They greet you with a complimentary cocktail, and the service is just fantastic! So friendly and professional, helpful, and provided a perfect balance of attention and letting you enjoy yourselves. 

The food was really good too! Can't complain there. The portions were small, but fair with the amount of plates you get. I left feeling comfortably full. 

They took note of it being our anniversary and added a nice touch to our dessert.

Everything from start to finish was just top notch! Would definitely recommend visiting.
This was truly an amazing experience.  The food was EXCELLENT and the service was fantastic. My favorite was the pistachio cake and the hamachi crudo. Highly recommend it to everyone!!

Lovely place to hold a special occasion dinner. You have a limited number of options for each course, which means they're all perfectly executed. Service is unmatched in the city. Staff is knowledgeable and willing to share what they know.

You're able to order extra items for a surcharge, which I recommend if you're unsure about what to choose.

We had high hopes for this place, but at $125 per person before tax + tip it was just... not that worth it, unless you have unlimited money to spend. I've had meals for half the price which impressed me much more than Vetri. Coming from out of town, Vetri was supposed to be the food highlight of our trip, but everyone in our party was let down.

The good:
- Atmosphere was nice, dimly lit and relaxing
- Service was friendly
- The appetizers and desserts were fantastic!

The meh:
- The rest of the food was decent but not excellent. I'm writing this review one month later, and besides the appetizers and desserts I can't remember the rest. Pretty unmemorable.
- If I hadn't eaten the complimentary bread, I would not have left full

Also, we found out afterwards that the cocktails they offer you in the beginning are complimentary, so make sure to get them. We didn't know and they didn't tell us so we didn't opt for them. The rest of the drinks (coffee, tea, additional alcohol, etc.) are not included.

To be totally honest, I'm probably not the target demographic for this restaurant since I rarely do high dining. If you have major cash to spend, maybe you'll find Vetri totally worth it for the price. But if this is a bit of a splurge and you're spending this much for a special occasion, I would reconsider.
We came in on a public holiday and we're served so quickly after a long day. The food was fresh and the place was clean. It was well priced and the servings were good.
The pasta dishes are superb but the wine and cocktails were not well matched both times we have come here. Our waitress made excellent recommendations though and no complaints about the service.

When I go to dinner I expect to buy dinner, but going to Vetri means paying for an experience! 

In past visits the offering was a chefs choice menu with several courses, usually including a pasta. On this recent visit diners could choose their selections. 

Fish, pasta, and offerings far outside of traditional fare. Exquisitely presented with various sauces or complimentary flavors that will take you on a culinary adventure found in very few places nationwide. 

A small venue of a hundreds year old row home allow a host of knowledge, passionate, professional servers with complete understanding of the dishes to fill in every detail of what you are eating. 

Get the wonderful wine pairing from the resident sommelier and let her take you through Italy and describe varieties you likely haven't tried. 

Fun. Just fun and palate expanding. An experience you'll cherish.

We celebrated our 50 th wedding anniversary at Vetri Cuccia, having the most amazing dinner one only can dream of. The entire staff was beyond excellent, as was each course. This wonderful restaurant has our highest recommendation.

It's been a long time since I've sat in a fine dining restaurant and I'm so glad my love chose this one. It was his birthday so we decided to visit this restaurant. He's been many times in the past and it was my very first time. The dining experience was very intimate and cozy we had a great view of the chefs table from our location. The service was phenomenal we were greeted and taken directly to our seating area. Then our server explained the menu and discussed a special that would replace the "second" portion. The cocktails were amazing and we didn't have to wait long after finishing a course to starting a new one. I'm looking forward to going again hopefully without it being a special occasion.

Without a doubt my favorite restaurant - I like it more than the few Michelin 3-star restaurants I've been lucky enough to eat at. Nothing about it - food, service, comfort - is less than amazing. Worth making a special trip for.

Did the tasting menu with wine pairings- so delicious and so much fun! Waitstaff was great, walked us through everything, answered all our questions, and taught us a lot about Italian food & wine! Perfect night out.

Overall: This was a bucket list dinner and well worth the wait. We had a great time at Vetri eating til we burst. You can tell that the chefs have incredible skill and training. Even the bread for the table is house made and the lightest fluffiest bread I have ever had. 

The sweet onion crepe was one of the best things I've eaten, ever. The broiled oysters were fabulous. The branzino was delicious and buttery. The chocolate polenta cake was literally the best chocolate cake I've ever eaten. 

The only thing I wouldn't do again is the spinach gnocchi. I believe I heard the waiter explain that they dont use ricotta or flour, it's basically just a spinach puree dumpling. While wonderfully done, I just don't personally love spinach this much that I can skip all the other things that go into a gnocchi. 

The last thing I wanted to say is that Vetri felt: cozy. It felt comfortable and approachable despite being high end dining. Not at all pretentious. 

While I can't say we'll be back any time super soon, it was an awesome experience and I'm grateful I finally got to try it!
Always amazing!!! The wine pairings are perfect. Service is out of this world. One of the best!!!

business.name: Rat's Restaurant
business.categories: Bars, French, Restaurants, Nightlife, Breakfast & Brunch

reviews.text: Haven't been here in quite a few years so we were looking forward to what had been some great meals in the past. Unfortunately this was not to be. Appetizers were generally good to excellent. My foie gras was excellent as were the two apps my sons ordered (bone marrow for one and French Onion soup for the other). My wife ordered the spiced pear and frisée salad which was OK as the pears were heavily spiced and the burrata was too cold and thus tasteless. Entrees were a big miss. Pasta dish was so garlicky and salty that it was inedible. I ordered the hangar steak which was tough and consisted of only a few slices of beef. The plating was terrible for the steak, served with a few sad looking potatoes and green beans. The two sides we ordered (Brussels sprouts and squash) were underdone and uninspired. Overall the restaurant feels tired and dated.

Came to Rat's for Christmas Eve lunch and really enjoyed my meal. First, our server did a fine job, but I was a little surprised by various staff cursing (one of the hostesses said GDI to another hostess right in front of us as they were figuring out our table, and another staff member dropped the F bomb a few feet away from us when we were eating). Not the biggest deal, but kind of brought down the classiness of the place, I think.

Anyway, I got the escargots for an appetizer and it was decent, although pretty filling (and thus a mistake in a day full of food!). For my entree, I decided to get the seafood salad, and I really enjoyed it! Definitely a big hit with me, and while I ended up too full after eating it, I would 100% eat it again :) Beer selection was fine.

Overall, I would definitely consider coming back here, especially since I still need to tour the Sculpture Park!

We took our kids to Grounds for Sculpture to close out winter break and made reservations for lunch at Rat's. It exceeded our wildest expectations of a place to grab an elevated lunch while keeping our three kids under 10 engaged (which almost never happens). From the moment we walked in, Sasha, the host, warmly welcomed our family and kids and set the tone for the lunch. Our server, Austin, was incredibly patient with us and our kids and knowledgeable about the menu (I can never make up my mind). As we were leaving, our oldest ask when we could come again!

We went to this place on Christmas Eve, and it was probably the worst "dining" experience of our lives. In all honesty, the casual bars around here have better food at a fraction of the price with excellent service delivered by truly sincere people--they are your neighbors, and they see it that way.

I'm not just talking about a server in the weeds, or something that was less than perfect. The server was rude, dismissive, he didn't ask us if we wanted dessert, skipped bread servings that are supposed to be highlights...I can't use the word I want to use to describe him. Terrible, not even trying to fake it...

I grew up in my family's restaurant in this area and I'm no male Karen by any stretch....it was bad, trust me.

Rat's in an undeniably special space on some amazing grounds, and it is beautiful outside in the summer. But the way we were treated tonight will prevent us from returning, in spite of the conciliatory tone of the manager on our way out.

Just close for the day if you don't have adequate, capable staff, it's understandable. Don't make the money at the expense of members of your community when you can't hold up your end of the bargain.

It's a real pity that the service and ambience are poor as the setting has much promise.  Tonight after visiting Night Forms we decided to eat at Rats.  Cocktails were tasteless and boring to look at, appetisers,  just odd, pre spread foie gras and onion soup with a pinesol flavour.  Nigh on an hours wait for entrées, with no offer of a second drink.  Service was non existent.   

Not sure who Rats is intended for but it was a big miss for our family of 4.

Celebrated an anniversary there.I asked for a nice section to sit in but was put into a dark cold corner. Had to cover the floor vents with the menus to keep warm  lol. When we first got there we were hardly greeted by the hostess who then completely forgot to seat us so we waited 20 minutes and she used the excuse "I think someone else took your reservation". What? The food was OK but the only thing going for rats is the atmosphere and I would imagine it is 1000 times better when the weather is nice and you can sit by the water and outside on the patio.

I was happily surprised with the quality of food at Rat's! We came to celebrate a friend's birthday. They provided complementary madeleines at the end.

The service was very nice but on the slower side. We were there for 2.5 hours, and it's not like we were particularly slow ourselves. 

The charcuterie board was standard, but good! The escargot was not how I expected it to be served. Flavor was good but the price point is debatable.

Of the 4 entrées we ordered (short rib, prime rib, duck breast, hanger steak), the hanger steak and duck breast were the most notable. The hanger steak was perfectly tender. The short rib seemed a bit dry, and the prime rib temperature was not as accurate. 

Overall, pretty good flavor. For the price we paid, I did expect a bit more consistency across the board. I'd still recommend trying it out, especially for the beautiful atmosphere being right in Grounds for Sculpture!

We have been coming here for over 20 years. Our family of 7 went there today for a get together.  Yes, I understand that they may have been understaffed. However, most of the appetizers we ordered were barely warm or inedible. The French onion soup had no bread in the bottom of the bowl and tasted straight out of a can. The shrimp were a bit too salty. The escargot with puff pastry...the escargot was barely warm and tasteless; the puff pastry was soggy. How long had our food been sitting there waiting for delivery?  We had ordered the charcuterie app when we first sat down. It didn't show up until the rest of the food was delivered. We had planned to munch on this while the rest of the food was being prepared.   Well...another restaurant off the list; I see no reason to ever go back.

It was our first time here! The food was amazing, the ambiance is amazing, service amazing as well. Staff is just as friendly as they are professional, and the views are definitely something to talk about. Cassandra took care of us & she got everything out timely and politely! Thanks again, wish we lived closer so we could return, but it made our trip to NJ pleasant.

I've been to Rat's numerous times over the years and have never been disappointed. We just went for Thanksgiving and were absolutely delighted that they were able to keep the dinner at their usual high quality with the same elegant atmosphere. The courses were tasty and delicious and we couldn't believe the reasonable price for all of the food we received. Going out for dinner on the holiday is usually a mistake but NOT at Rat's, we highly recommend you try it!

We went for Thanksgiving dinner this year and there were four of us my wife and two neighbors.
I ordered the pear arugula salad which was just OK nothing to rave about my appetizer was duck liver pate which was a little bit of pate on top of stale toast I couldn't even taste any liver in the pate. I ordered the turkey dinner they said you would get a mix of white and dark meat I only got dry white over cooked meat pieces. A quarter cup of stuffing was served -a small smear of mashed potatoes and about 7 string beans. They served a thimble sized container of cranberry sauce which was half full. The dessert I chose was the pumpkin bread pudding which didn't resemble bread pudding at all but a round lump of stale pieces of bread chunks with no taste of pumpkin whatsoever. I left hungry and I was very disappointed. The other guests and my wife were also upset regarding their dinners each couple paid over $178. We did have 4 drinks which added to the bill. Next year we'll be cooking our own dinner at home-- Service was also lacking had to keep asking the waiter to fill glass bring more bread- where is our meal -but we do understand it's still Covid related....

Beautiful scenery, delicious food.  The charcuterie selection was amazing. Wait staff could pay a bit more attention but our server was very nice regardless. The hostess was okay, she didn't seem too happy.  Will definitely return based on the food and scenery.

Venue is beautiful- love how you can walk around after dining and also have fun with sculptures placed throughout the venue. It's definitely entertaining- Food tasted delicious as well. All of the dishes I had from there were all very satisfying. I took one star off for cleanliness. I reserved an outdoor table which was a great choice after all but they placed my utensils directly on the glass table without napkins being under it or anything. The table were all glass that's not being sanitized after each party leaves so I felt extremely uncomfortable after seeing that. Our server was a bit too busy and always had to look for him to get his attention. I would recommend this place for post pandemic to be safe.
The food is delicious and well executed. The wine list is pretty impressive.  Our server was great and attentive.  A wonderful place to eat after a day at the Grounds for sculpture.

The 4 stars are for the atmosphere and the creme brulee. I had the turkey Croissant and it was okay. The brussel sprouts were also okay, but not something I would order again. My friend reported that he enjoyed his salad, but since he was able to eat half of my sandwich (which I was perfectly fine with because nothing about the sandwich made me desire to eat more than half), I don't think sufficient food was provided to satisfy hunger pains. 

Given how pricey the food is, I assumed the food would be crafted in a manor that is more than average, but the creme brulee was very enjoyable and the atmosphere is absolutely beautiful and comfortable enough to make me want to come back again .... for a drink and a creme brulee.

Really used to love going to this restaurant, we usually go once a year.
The gardens are beautiful but it really stops there.
We  went early to hang at the bar and take in the ambiance.
Neither bartenders wanted to engage at all with the patrons.
( they where not that busy).
we all ordered French onion soup and all portions sizes where filled half way and warm at best.
My seafood risotto was less then warm sent back twice!
did not have to be piping hot but warm to touch would have nice.

It was my wife's birthday we ordered 2 desserts they both came out of kitchen at separate times.
But  what became funny was a third birthday dessert arrived shortly after. Ok free dessert as we finished a 4th unordered birthday candle dessert showed up!!
 But the number one reason I will not forget or return back to this charming restaurant would be this $2.00 charge.
I ordered an oban scotch on the rocks, it was $19 fair enough, wait for it... and a $2.00 charge separate line item on our bill for $2.00 for rocks. So whoever the genius in this organization that came up with hey I know how to increase revenue let's charge for a glass of Ice!
Brilliant let's leave our guests with that to remember when they leave us!
hahaha 
Joe

Beautiful place,special atmosphere,romantic surroundings.
Great service and elegant foods.

If you haven't visited Grounds for Sculpture yet (beautiful park like setting with acres of amazing art that people ages 1-100 will enjoy!), or if you do and haven't tried Rat's yet.......its a perfect one-two combination ! 

I admit, I take my family to Grounds for Sculpture (GFS) quite often but only went to Rats the other day with my wife and what a treat. Spring and Fall make perfect weather for a nice lunch or dinner on the patio. Food is excellent and the servers are friendly and accommodating. The hand cut potato wedges were amazing, seasonal lemonade and sangria were very refreshing. Plus at the end......my wife and I split the chocolate cremeux - perfection !

My boyfriend and I went to this restaurant for our anniversary looking for great food and ambiance. The venue is beautiful, especially the outdoor patio, with views of the little river and some sculptures. The food was okay. We had the mezze appetizer which was probably the highlight of the meal- the dips were great. However the pickled vegetables seemed to be out of a jar. I ordered the fettuccine pasta with pesto and I really couldn't get past the amount of oil on the plate, the pasta was doused in it. In addition, the flavors weren't very strong and there was very little tomato and corn. My boyfriend ordered the scallops, which tasted good, but there was quite a bit of sand that he had to constantly pick out while eating. We ordered the chocolate tart for dessert, which was great.

Excellent lunch.  Enjoying Grounds for Sculpture and had to visit Rat's for lunch.  Great service with Brian.  Got the charcuterie and cheese board - nice size and very tasty.  We had the heirloom tomato salad with burrata and also the foie gras toast as main meals and got a side of Brussels sprouts.  Everything was amazing.  Added a lemon  tart.

We saw this in our local paper and decided to visit the Sculpture Garden and dinner at Rat's. 
The Sculpture Garden was impressive and worth the trip.  Rat's on the hand was not. The location and the theme is impressive but the food and the service was not. 
Our waitress was friendly but inept. She disappeared on a regular basis for long periods of time. Our order was not correct and they offered to correct but the correction took twenty minutes. 
The short ribs were tasty but dry.  Dessert was another long wait   The fish was delicious. 
Over all very disappointing!!

We had an incredible time here. Our waitress was Cassandra and she was lovely! I had the branzino and the "Sunset at Monet Bridge" cocktail for lunch. The restaurant is a mini museum in and of itself, and I'd recommend taking a nice look around you while you walk to your table! The decor is so meticulously chosen, and really worth taking a second to appreciate. 
       Rats is appropriate for all occasions, whether it's a quick bite before exploring Grounds for Sculpture, a fancy anniversary dinner, an afternoon catching up with an old friend, or a drink at the bar after a long day spent walking around the Grounds.
     I can't recommend Rats enough. There's a sense of unique joy there, and it's also reflected through the menu!

Visited Rats for the first time and I am in love! Celebrated our engagement and we both loved our meals. I would have given Rats 5 stars but we had to wait a really really long time for our food. Toured the grounds before heading to our reservation. We arrived at 7:45pm and did not leave until 10pm! Not sure if food was delayed bc there was a rehearsal dinner going on at the same time or if they were understaffed. Yes, the meal was expensive however we were already expecting to pay a lot. Hostess and staff were so friendly! We mentioned our recent engagement and they offered us a complimentary glass of champagne each! Drinks were strong but we're not complaining. My steak was probably one of the best and most tender/soft steak I've ever had! My fiancé ordered the seafood risotto and it was so creamy and filled with a variety of seafood. We will definitely be coming back for another special occasion.

More for the experience not the food. Forgot to ask for drinks, over priced d'Angelo's prime rib sandwich. Only reason why it's worth it is the statue trail. 

Crohns bathroom review: 
Nice smelling bathroom with a nice playlist of soft music. Sink was fancy but school foam soap  7.5/10

Had a lovely experience at Rat's. I had been to grounded for sculpture but this was my first time eating at Rat's. 

We had initially made a reservation to eat outside but due to our dinner being later in the evening and the seating being by the pond, there were a lot of bugs so we opted to sit inside.  I had a watermelon frozé and scallops for my main course. The scallops were served with radishes and bacon over a corn purée. I ate every last bite of my meal so you can say it was delicious! My husband had the short rib and gave it a 5 star rating! 

We definitely hope to be back to check it out for lunch!

business.name: Butcher and Singer
business.categories: Restaurants, Steakhouses, American (Traditional)

reviews.text:
Solid steakhouse in the heart of center city. Barmen consistently demonstrate their knowledge of building pleasure through flavor. The mastery at the broiler and grill will not disappoint you. The room's two-story ceiling brings memories of grand days gone by, once a bank lobby? So cool. 

BAR
Liquor list features many local Pennsylvania brands, and if you're daring, ask your barman to make you one that takes you off the beaten path!
Mine was my simple sapphire martini ($20), in and out, twist, stirred. Excellent. 

SERVICE
Tuxedoed servers and staff are the norm, and the formal style of service is the standard at steakhouses like this across the nation. 

AMBIENCE
Dishwasher station is busy and loud. The "plate clanking" and pot banging volume is quite high, as is the symphonic buzz of kitchen printers heralding your order in concert. It would make a marvelous background-noise track, "busy restaurant"! I'd certainly buy it for my Apple TV!

Music tracks overhead are a mix of big band and fast trio jazz, accented by bursts of trumpet and scatty Singers. 

But my favorite is the discreet sculpture of a bull's head with horns, mounted at the center of the far wall. Ha!

THE COURSE
Tonight's oysters ($19)  were huge, creamy samples from Maryland, and some delightful briny ones from Massachusetts. 
The mignonette was wonderfully chunky at the bottom, not the watery vinegar with "floaty bits" one usually gets elsewhere. Great flavor. 
And the horseradish was freshly shaved, airy, and dare I say, light? also a special treat.  

The 8oz filet mignon ($46), "black and blue" arrived perfectly hard-hard-broiled and then raw and cold in the center. 
Not that charcoal shoe-leather black you get from the chef to punish you for ordering "well done", just perfectly done. Bravo!
The warm plate brought up the temp so it was cool instead of cold as I made my way through it, Wow!
I added some finishing salt to each bite, and realized this is truly the way to enjoy a steak. This size. This way.  
The delectable mushrooms and onions ($12) side was the perfect accompaniment. 

Finishing sweetly was a delightful baked pear sorbet ($9) and Calvados ($20) digestif. 

BUT THE BUGS
Special flying insect friends were companions tonight, interested in  beverages, the butter and bread and more. They only swarmed every five minutes or so, but Shucks!
Honestly with more "pre

BOBBLING ALONG
On a more personal note, with my E-badge not renewed for '22 after 13 in a row and 14 in the community, I must admit some relief that I can now review more casually, tell more of a personal story, and without the pressure that "mine will appear before others, so I had _better_ be "just the facts ma'am" concise,  do it right, and not waste your time with rambling!l" 
Now I know that these will disappear into the babbling swath of bobbleheads, never to be noticed, well, except for you followers and dear friends from so very many years together!! 
Let me know if you line this more narrative casual style better.

I somehow ignored my addiction to the dry-aged ribeyes at Del Frisco's and finally tried this old school Center City gem! Boy was I NOT disappointed! Fantastic food and excellent, friendly (even funny) service!

Our Porterhouse for Two was cooked to a perfect medium rare and was super-flavorful! Our stuffed hash browns and creamed spinach sides were delicious! And the biscuits were so good -- buttery, flakey, melt in your mouth good -- that we ordered a second basket!

And then I saw it...

The dessert menu had BAKED ALASKA!

I was like: "No, way! They have Baked Alaska!?!?" This is like the dessert of legends -- an after dinner delicacy I've only heard about and read about, but have never actually seen on any menu anywhere. In fact, I think it's one of those ancient American desserts that went the way of the dinosaur back in the late 1960s (along with Sinatra-era treats like Clams Casino), never to be seen on an American menu again...UNTIL NOW! But to be honest, when I read about this dessert years ago, I was like: "Why would anyone think ice cream baked into a meringue is even a good idea?" But I LOVED IT! Never tasted a merengue this good! And the apricots!

So, yeah, it will now become easier to stave off the Del Frisco's habit if this place is the steak destination (meaning, they will see me again).

Biscuits w/ Honey Butter: 5/5
Tuna Tartare: 5/5
Porterhouse Steak for Two: 5/5
Creamed Spinach: 5/5
Stuffed Hashbrown: 5/5
Baked Alaska: 5/5
Blackberry Cosmopolitan: 4/5

Appetizers were good, drinks were average but entree's were subpar especially King Salmon which was bland and soggy. Staff was responsive, took a note and got it off our check. Overall, not worth the buck.
This is hands down my favorite steak in Philly. It's inside is an old bank so the place is old school and really neat to sit and eat.
Food was incredible, best filet I have ever had.  The green beans are incredible.  Basically anything you order is worth it.  Perfect for a date night

I made a reservation for my boyfriend's birthday on a Friday evening a month in advance and we were both very excited to try out Butcher and Singer! We were promptly seated in a nice, private table - which I appreciate for a steakhouse where they usually pack you in like sardines. We brought a special bottle of wine for the occasion (corkage fee I think is $30) and ordered appetizers - Mac and cheese and Caesar salad. Both were delicious as were the complimentary biscuits. My boyfriend ordered the bone-in delmonico, I ordered the bone-in filet, and we shared the creamed spinach and mashed potatoes. Dinner and appetizers all came out with perfect timing and we're delicious! This is where things started to go downhill. We began eating our dinner and within 30 minutes we're done and ready to have things boxed up. We sat there for another 30 minutes waiting for our server... we watched other tables have their server check on them multiple times and the person filling our water came by probably 5 times. We finally asked the man filling our water to box up our meals as we had already been there 2 hours and had somewhere to be. Finally, our server came by and when we didn't order dessert, made us feel bad (believe me, dessert and espresso martinis are my favorite part of a meal so we usually would have ordered). For a place where you are dropping $100+ per person, I am beyond disappointed with the service.

I was so nervous about out dining experience, after reading such mixed reviews. Thankfully we had a wonderful dinner. The steak was definitely not the star of the show, it was still good, but id have to the biscuits and honey butter were outstanding. We got the truffle butter and it was a really nice complement to the filet mignon. the creamed spinach, mac and cheese and stuffed hashbrowns were all delicious, though I do wish the mac & cheese came with a breadcrumbs cause it was one note. we got the baked Alaska and crème brûlée for dessert and they were both great, the baked Alaska, The meringue was so perfectly fluffy and marshmallowy. I seen a lot of comments about the staff, I have to say our service was exceptional. We had a last-minute add-on and they were very accommodating, our server Leah checked on us frequently. The thing that really sets them apart was when the bus boy what are deserts in the end my sister made a comment to me 'oh yeah I forgot to tell them' It was my other sisters birthday. The waiter immediately took back one of the desserts and brought it back with a candle and a happy birthday sign. What I come back, maybe, was it worth it, absolutely!

When we arrived, we didn't receive the most friendly welcome, so I was slightly dubious at first.   The service did improve as a different waitress served us and was very friendly, putting us at ease.   Our drinks arrived promptly, although there was a little wait for our food, but we didn't mind so much. I ordered the Filet Mignon and my partner ordered the Wedge Salad.   I was a little put off when I saw my chicken burger, as the chicken looked like it had been overcooked.   However, it was actually nice once I bit into it. I had to pick the New York Strip out as it was very chewy and undercooked for my taste, and I normally love New York Strip! The onion rings tasted pleasant, but they were very greasy.   My partner really enjoyed his burger and the chips were lovely too.   I'm aware a lot of places are implementing this optional service charge, but I really don't personally like it.   We were going to tip anyway and probably would have tipped a bit more than 10%, but I really don't like being pressured into it by having it added to the bill.   Overall, a fairly enjoyable experience, but we probably wouldn't rush back in a hurry!

Classy. Dining. Experience. Those three words will be your takeaways after you visit this posh eatery in the heart of Center City. My dining party had an easy time getting reservations two weeks ago and when we walked in the door and greeted the host, within 15 seconds we were whisked to our cozy table and gave our drink order. We chatted with our friendly waiter, sipped our sparkling water and chose what amounted to a feast. Crab cakes (moist and delicate and delectable). Butcher salad (large bowl full of garden deliciousness mixed with provolone and prosciutto and who knows what else but we got down with it). Buttermilk biscuits that will make you want to steal the recipe. Twin lobster tails with drawn butter were large and perfectly cooked, not rubbery. The salmon was flaky and moist and every bite got better. Spinach and Mac and cheese sides, I have to admit, we loved them but could hardly eat them because we were saving room for dessert. Yes, dessert. Mouthwatering Baked Alaska. It was our first time having that dessert and it did not disappoint. We left the restaurant happy and reeling with food babies on our belly and we laughed and raved about the experience while we walked the four blocks to our hotel. 

Butcher & Singer was the full package. Dreamy and golden and atmospheric, but also intimate. Delicious and decadent, but also accessible. Listen, you want to visit the place and you should. If your money is funny, save a few hundred to come here and visit for a special occasion. You'll have to excuse me, I need to call and make our reservations for 2022.

Simply wonderful! I took my family here last night to celebrate Christmas Eve, and it  was lovely. I wish to go on and on and on, but it's Christmas today, and I've got to prepare to spend time with family. The top three for me were: customer service, the ambience and the biscuits. My waiter - Jared (I believe) was excellent!  We ordered lamb chops, twin lobster tails, the rib eye, mac and cheese, stuffed hash browns, mashed potatoes, creamed spinach, the wedge salad, the butcher salad and the Caesar salad - I could be missing a few items but everything was lovely! This place didn't miss.

The concierge at the Four Seasons Hotel recommended this restaurant, and I am so glad he did!

The hubs and I split everything from the King Crab Cocktail, Caesar Salad, and Delmonico with two lobster tails. The best part, the chef slices the steak for you. The stuffed hash browns and Brussel sprouts were to die for; although, the hubs thought the sprouts could have used a tad more salt. We finished off our meal with the lemon icebox pie which was a tasty substitute for key lime pie. The service was impeccable! We were pleasantly surprised to learn that our waiter, Dirk, had also worked at one of our favorite restaurants in Charleston, SC. 

I definitely recommend going with the waiter's suggestions! While you probably can't go wrong with anything you order, these folks are the professionals and are going to know what's really working well at the restaurant!
Great for a fancy evening! Filet was perfectly cooked. The sides are to die for. Pricey but nice for a fancy occasion

Best steakhouse that I had the pleasure of trying during my trip to Philadelphia. The escargot was the perfect balance of garlic and salt. The old fashion was one of the best I have ever had. The steak and side dishes as well as the service was unmatched. Even when I didn't order a dessert for my birthday, the waiter still brought me a small scoop of ice cream with a happy birthday message on it. Amazing experience overall, don't miss out.

5 Stars for the atmosphere: gorgeous venue with high ceilings and tall windows that draw your eyes upward. Beautiful centerpiece chandelier, and thoughtful upward lighting placement, though the overall restaurant is pretty dim. I believe the location was converted from an old bank, and the owners did a tasteful job in the structures they kept to provide a memorable dining experience. 

5 Stars for service: our waitress was fun, attentive, and accommodating. 

My party of 4 was seated in the upper level, and unfortunately did not find the benches/low back chairs very comfortable. It was definitely a bit harder to get out of, particularly with the height difference of our party members, and the close table placement (our bench was backed fully up to the table next to us)! 

The food was good, though definitely "heavy." I wish I did not add Oscar to my steak as the béarnaise sauce was way too overpowering, even after scraping it off!  The stuffed hash browns were pretty good, though there weren't any other sides that particularly stood out. I would recommend trying the Baked Alaska dessert, at least for the fun experience!

Dirk was our server. He put up with us the entire evening after warning him that we were  going to be classless derelicts in an otherwise classy joint. He knew his audience and didn't disappoint the whole evening. Wine selection was fantastic. Had the seafood tower and tried escargot for the first time too, both were great. From reading the other reviews, I was somewhat hesitant to order my steak rare for fears of being even more undercooked, but ordered the Delmonico steak rare anyway. Came out fabulous and cooked to perfection. Had one of every side dish for the group and a baked potato. Hard to screw up side dishes, but my only issue was the creamed spinach.  It just wasn't on point and I feel I could have made better myself.  Had the baked Alaska for dessert, but tried a bite on the tart, cheesecake too. All were soooo good. Great time, great server and great ambiance. We'll done Dirk!

Excellent food on this first visit. Came here on a business dinner. We ordered a good bottle of Barolo and then some oysters which were fresh. My guests ordered some large cuts of beef while I ordered the halibut. We also ordered some sides. The food was good. My halibut was excellent, probably one of the best one I've had in a very long time. I'll be coming back to this classy place

Amazing! We had the halibut and the Delmonico steak. For sides we had the broccoli, mashed potatoes and Mac and cheese. Everything was cooked to perfection! Ricky was our server and he was amazing too!!!  Oh and the biscuits with the sweet butter were unbelievable!

FAVORITE PLACE in Philly HANDS DOWN! Probably one of the top 5 Best Restaurants ever visited in my lifetime. 

I've been frequenting Butcher and Singer for years now and absolutely love this place! I come here for special occasions, important milestone and sometimes when I get a Friday evening craving, haha. They are deliciously consistent which speaks volumes for me. 

Highly recommend the best steak of the house: The Delmonico cooked at a medium rare temperature with the Truffle Butter addition. DO IT, you only live once ;). 

Sides I love: Mash Potatoes, the Hash, and the Cream of Spinach. (Stock up on those carbs)! 

BEST COCKTAIL IN THE WORLD: The Blackberry Cosmo 

Don't forget to give the butter biscuits a try. You'd never think biscuits would be a showstopper at a steakhouse. Believe me, you'll probably order a second round for desert they are SO GOOD!

Took my dad out for his birthday dinner. Overall a great experience. We arrived around 6:30 pm with a reservation and at the time there weren't many people, but once it hit 7pm, the restaurant looked full. Our server was nice and welcoming. There was a table sitting right above/behind our heads, which was a bit disruptive - I could hear every word of their conversation 

Unfortunately, i completely forgot  to take a picture of the steaks we ordered. They were good, but I think Barclay Prime is better. I normally get medium rare, but I would get medium here. The onion soup was the best part about this dinner. Love the cheesiness. We ordered so many different things I don't think I fully appreciated each dish because I was so full. We ordered the stuffed hash brown because it was a fan favorite on Yelp. I thought it was okay. It's like warm potato hash inside a giant has brown. The raw oysters were also very small - the last time I had raw oysters was in Boston, so maybe I just had too high of an expectation? My dad loved the creme brûlée, but again, the banana pudding at Barclay Prime is so much better - has more flavor, fresher. 

Overall: I'd give it a 7/10 rating. I don't know if the food is really worth the price. Id probably go back for the onion soup and the Mac and cheese, but this is a steakhouse and I didn't think it was all that special. 

Giving it a higher rating for its service.

I expected to like this restaurant a lot more.  Generally, I am in awe of Stephen Starr and his empire, and have had many good experiences at his restaurants.  This wasn't a bad experience, per se, just left a little to be desired, hence the four star review.  

We showed up early for our reservation and found two seats at the bar.  The bartender was clearly in the weeds, yet proficient regardless.  Still, there wasn't one word or gesture on his part to make us feel welcome or happy we were sitting at his bar.  He actually stressed me out.  

I discovered two texts from the hostess to let us know our table was available only after my husband went over to check - why not walk a few feet and let us know in person, in case we were not glued to our phones?  No one offered to take our coats, and they were awkward to hang over the back of the chairs.  Our waiter was very personable but amateurish.  Wine service was lacking and his explanation as to why he was recommending we order our steak medium instead of medium rare made no sense so we didn't listen to him - bad choice.

Hits and misses among the food.  Biscuits and honey butter were divine - as in, conversation came to an abrupt halt as we savored them.  Lots of restauranteurs miss out on an opportunity to impress with the bread basket - not S.S.  This boded well for the rest of our meal.  I thought the seafood tower was a bargain, and totally delicious - so much sweet lobster and crab, beautiful shrimp cocktail, and spanking fresh oysters with interesting sauces.  I liked the Oysters Rockefeller, too - plump, meaty oysters with a refined coating of green crumbs. My husband said they needed salt.  Our steak was the biggest disappointment.  We ordered a ribeye special, medium rare, our generally preferred temperature.  It came out nearly raw and very chewy/sinewy.  The side of bearnaise didn't come until we asked a runner for it - not even sure it was bearnaise, but too salty, regardless.   The creamed spinach was the best I ever had - we both practically licked the bowl clean.  

Lots of tourists, lots of folks from nearby NJ here for a special occasion, some moneyed looking Philadelphians there to see and be seen - made for some excellent people watching enhanced by the theater-like shape of the room - brilliant.
Great Filet, good service, friendly staff. Good place for a business meeting.
Server Ashley was so great. Amazing filer mignon and salmon. Great atmosphere. Seriously recommend this place for a special occasion!

The Culinary Adventures of Tom Coghlan
It was Center City Restaurant Week ! Three Courses for $35. The third Restaurant I chose was Butcher and Singer, 1500 Walnut Street, where "Old-world Hollywood sparks meet unparalleled steaks and chops." Butcher and Singer, a Starr Restaurant is the eleventh in my Starr Restaurant series... I entered Butcher and Singer for the first time and was impressed by the tall marble columns that reached the 25 foot high ceiling.  Marbleized tapestries filled the voids. the low lighting took a few seconds for me to adjust to... I then found the bar,  where I met my sever Willie, who like the other servers was dressed in a tuxedo like suit. I ordered a flute of prosecco, and reviewed the menu. For my first course, I had, Crab Cake Lemon Aioli and Fennel Slaw. When the Crab cake arrived it was served atop a white sauce next to a fennel Cole slaw. I no longer had the menu, so I asked Willie what the sauce was... He told me it was from the slaw... I knew that wasn't right, but I didn't want to dispute him... I later found out it was a Lemon Aioli. It complimented the crab cake well, as did the fresh parsley... The crab cake was predominantly crab... The way I like ! The slaw was house made and fresh. For my second course I had an 8 oz. Filet served medium rare, and a glass of Pinot Nior. The filet was thick and cooked just the way I ordered. It was tender and flavorful and cut like butter ! A bit of arugula and olive oil was on the side, The wine was PERFECT ! For a vegetable, i ordered Creamed Spinach which came in its own small bowl. It too was house made with the perfect amount of garlic and it was FRESH ! it still had a bit of crunch to it and all the flavors exploded with each bite ! For the third dessert course I ordered, Chocolate Pot de Crème with Whipped cream. It was a rich pudding served in a glass with fresh strawberries, whipped cream and little balls of chocolate. I took my time eating it with my Sambuca and Cappuccino, savoring every bite, and every sip !        https://butcherandsinger.com

Our dining experience, at Butcher and Singer, was superb. The pleasurable experience began with the introduction of our waiter, Brian-he was engaging and helpful and provided excellent service-to hear his description of the items on the menu, allowed you to know exactly what you were ordering . When we were served our food, we were not disappointed. From appetizers to entree to dessert, the whole experience was extremely delightful and incredibly delicious. Oh yeah, I almost forgot,  a big shout out to the biscuits-wow!!

I want to start by saying if you want to have an amazing meal then this is the place for you. The service was horrendous not due to lack of concern from the staff but due to understaffing. We had a 830p reservation and was told we had to wait because they didn't factor in tables staying longer which makes NO sense. What you did is overbook. They didn't offer any apologies or complimentary anything. The bartender took 20 mins to make two drinks and we sat at the table 10 mins before someone came over. It was our anniversary which they were aware of and did nothing as my husband planned. Let me add that it was a MONDAY! With these prices and their "reputation" I expected a much better experience overall.

business.name: Fork
business.categories: Burgers, American (New), Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch

reviews.text: Hadn't been to Fork in over 20 yrs but I can see why it's had longevity. Our server Rodney was fantastic- right level of wit, knowledge and attentiveness. I had the squash soup- it had a tartness which I enjoyed, plus I liked the addition of Thai basil. I got monk fish and the portion was huge- sat atop buttered leeks and came with roasted veggies. Dessert was a delicious coconut custard. The only downside was a ridiculously week coffee- seems to be a trend in the reviews. I would have sent it back, but since I was there for hours catching up with an old friend, I didn't want to push it.

I can understand why Fork is on the top 50 restaurants of Philadelphia with such a great staff and wonderful ambiance.  While the food menu may not be as extensive as other establishments in the city, the quality is present along with an extensive wine list to accompany the food.  I came by on a Wednesday evening around 7:30 in October and was surprised by the large number of people present but service was not slowed.  If you are in the lower end of Market Street, stop on by.

I had been to Fork once before, during their 20th anniversary celebration, for their "20 bites for 20 years" menu - everything was outstanding! So I was super excited to return for a work dinner recently. Everything was outstanding again! Even 5 years later. 

Ambience: 5. Seriously. So. Beautiful. High ceilings. Old, wood bar in the center. Perfectly lit, not too loud, intimate booths/tables with plenty of space between them. 

Service: 5. From the moment we walked in until we left we were well taken care of. Food came out quickly but not too fast - we had plenty of time to have a conversation in between courses. 

Food: 5. Really just SO excellent!!! Shared the brussel sprout starter, and then I had the monkfish. It was perfectly cooked and seasoned (I am one of those salters... and this did not need a single grain of salt). Portion size was also great - not overwhelming, but I was definitely full. Desserts (we tried one of each) were also great! 

Wine: 5. Wine list felt pricey? But glasses were reasonable and bottles based on glasses seemed more reasonable. We did not try cocktails (work dinner, remember?). 

I am already looking forward to my next trip to Fork!
This place NEVER disappoints. From the wine to the phenomenal food. Service is amazing and the owner is on site making sure people are happy. I recommend highly!
The cocktails were fantastic, although super expensive ($15 for a Moscow mule) We did not eat there. We enjoyed the atmosphere and chatting a bit with our bartender.

So disappointed. Nice menu, outside dining, delightful and attentive waiter, but the food was inedible.  Had always wanted to try grilled romaine, so ordered that salad.  Gritty dirt in the romaine.  inedible.  "sauce" and "bacon" almost not there.  2 skinny pieces of avocado.  Expensive.  Friend had the butternut squash soup with apple.  Said the apple was good, but soup was ... odd.  Finally, the weakest coffee I've ever had.  Ordered expresso.  Don't bother.  Total washout for $45++
That said, the waiter was good.

Oh this was a mess, poor outdoor seating. Terrible food..example a Cob salad that seemed as if the lettuce was not washed. A tiny bowl of squash soup with cut up fresh apples.. just substandard for the price.. and weak coffee.. we left and went to another more reliable place. The service was good though.. but I will never go back.

I'm going to keep this shirt and sweet. I had the $22 hamburger, and it's totally worth $23. Off the hook... prepared, assembled and presented with nothing but great taste. Fries match to perfection. Don't hesitate.

Someone told me to eat at Fork since it was a must try in Philly and everything was just ok. Food was ok, ambiance was like eating in a nice hotel lobby. Pros were staff was very nice and wine selection was decent. Very pricey for a meh experience.

Does anyone have anything bad to say about Forks? I've loved this place since my first meal there during restaurant week many moons ago. I still remember the bartender, and the lesson he gave my girlfriend and in on wine tasting and selection.
